results.title: A Party Picnicking Near a Village
results.tombstone: A Party Picnicking Near a Village, c. 1760–70. Louis Nicolas van Blarenberghe (French, 1716–1794). Gouache on antique laid paper; sheet: 12.2 x 16.8 cm (4 13/16 x 6 5/8 in.). The Cleveland Museum of Art, Bequest of Muriel Butkin, 2019.63
results.description: Louis Nicolas van Blarenberghe was known for drawings such as this one, which were executed on a small scale with exacting detail. His designs attracted the attention of the French monarchy, and he received numerous royal commissions. This work shows well-dressed figures enjoying outdoor leisure in a rural village. Its panoramic landscape and dense crowd were both characteristic of Van Blarenberghe’s miniaturist style.

results.title: Study for a Decoration for the Salle des Fêtes of the Town Hall of Paris's 11th arrondissement
results.technique: watercolor with black chalk framing lines on beige wove paper
results.tombstone: Study for a Decoration for the Salle des Fêtes of the Town Hall of Paris's 11th arrondissement, 1897. Victor Emile Prouvé (French, 1858–1943). Watercolor with black chalk framing lines on beige wove paper; sheet: 45.9 x 64.5 cm (18 1/16 x 25 3/8 in.). The Cleveland Museum of Art, Bequest of Muriel Butkin 2015.453
results.description: An avid draftsman, Victor Prouvé was known for his role in the École de Nancy, a group of artists active in the art nouveau movement, which integrated fine and decorative arts. This drawing relates to Prouvé's design for a mural intended to decorate the community center in the town hall of Paris's 11th arrondissement. By creating sophisticated designs for a broad public in such spaces, the artist sought to forge a role for vanguard art in everyday life.

results.title: Château Interior
results.technique: pen and ink, watercolor, gouache with graphite underdrawing on heavy cream wove paper
results.tombstone: Château Interior, 1834. V. Germain (French). Pen and ink, watercolor, gouache with graphite underdrawing on heavy cream wove paper; sheet: 41.9 x 67.1 cm (16 1/2 x 26 7/16 in.). The Cleveland Museum of Art, Bequest of Muriel Butkin 2018.1063
results.description: Little is known today about V. Germain, the artist who produced this drawing. Here, he focused on an interior scene with exacting detail, using a small group of figures at the sheet’s center to emphasize the massive scale of the castle where they have gathered.

results.title: Les Lavandières (Washerwomen)
results.technique: Watercolor with gouache and gum arabic
results.tombstone: Les Lavandières (Washerwomen), 1870–1880. Eugène Cicéri (French, 1813–1890). Watercolor with gouache and gum arabic ; sheet: 45.1 x 62.2 cm (17 3/4 x 24 1/2 in.). The Cleveland Museum of Art, Bequest of Muriel Butkin 2015.454

results.title: Landscape with Shepherds
results.technique: Watercolor with gouache, black chalk, and graphite
results.tombstone: Landscape with Shepherds, c. 1869. Jules Joseph Augustin Laurens (French, 1825–1901). Watercolor with gouache, black chalk, and graphite ; sheet: 45.4 x 64.1 cm (17 7/8 x 25 1/4 in.). The Cleveland Museum of Art, Bequest of Muriel Butkin 2015.455

results.title: Four Oxen Pulling a Plough
results.technique: Black chalk and gouache with graphite and gum Arabic and traces of white chalk in sky, squared for transfer in black chalk
results.tombstone: Four Oxen Pulling a Plough, 1853. Constant Troyon (French, 1810–1865). Black chalk and gouache with graphite and gum Arabic and traces of white chalk in sky, squared for transfer in black chalk; sheet: 35.5 x 28.1 cm (14 x 11 1/16 in.). The Cleveland Museum of Art, Bequest of Muriel Butkin 2015.452

results.title: Genets et Ronces (Broom and Brambles)
results.tombstone: Genets et Ronces (Broom and Brambles), 1860s. Jules Dupré (French, 1811–1889). Black, white, and red chalk ; sheet: 36.6 x 50.8 cm (14 7/16 x 20 in.). The Cleveland Museum of Art, Bequest of Muriel Butkin 2015.450

results.title: Portrait of a Seated Woman
results.technique: Black chalk heightened with white chalk on brown paper
results.tombstone: Portrait of a Seated Woman, 18th-19th century. Circle of François-André Vincent (French, 1746–1816). Black chalk heightened with white chalk on brown paper; sheet: 45.5 x 30.2 cm (17 15/16 x 11 7/8 in.). The Cleveland Museum of Art, Bequest of Muriel Butkin 2018.46
results.description: This drawing, presumably a study for a painted portrait, depicts a seated woman, dressed in a long gown and fashionable hat. Her casual pose, with one hand placed nonchalantly on her knee, her right elbow resting on the back of a chair, and a gaze unfocused on something outside the scene, gives the image an intimate informality.

results.title: Venus at the Forge of Vulcan
results.technique: Pen and brown ink, and brown wash (bistre) with red chalk and traces of graphite
results.tombstone: Venus at the Forge of Vulcan, 18th century. Louis Félix de La Rue (French, 1731–1777). Pen and brown ink, and brown wash (bistre) with red chalk and traces of graphite; sheet: 19.6 x 32.2 cm (7 11/16 x 12 11/16 in.); overall: 19.9 x 32.6 cm (7 13/16 x 12 13/16 in.). The Cleveland Museum of Art, Bequest of Muriel Butkin 2017.212
results.description: Venus, the goddess of love, descends on a cloud into the forge of Vulcan, the god of fire and metalworking. This scene illustrates an episode from Virgil’s Aeneid in which Venus has come to collect the suit of armor she asked Vulcan to make for her son, Aeneas. Several putti on the left play with the finished product.

results.title: La Sagesse
results.technique: Graphite, pen and black ink, and gray and black washes
results.measurements: Sheet: 39.4 x 27.8 cm (15 1/2 x 10 15/16 in.); Secondary Support: 39.6 x 28 cm (15 9/16 x 11 in.); Tertiary Support: 49.2 x 36.3 cm (19 3/8 x 14 5/16 in.)
results.tombstone: La Sagesse, late 18th- early 19th century. Alexandre-Evariste Fragonard (French, 1781–1850). Graphite, pen and black ink, and gray and black washes; sheet: 39.4 x 27.8 cm (15 1/2 x 10 15/16 in.); secondary support: 39.6 x 28 cm (15 9/16 x 11 in.); tertiary support: 49.2 x 36.3 cm (19 3/8 x 14 5/16 in.). The Cleveland Museum of Art, Bequest of Muriel Butkin 2018.47
results.description: Fragonard’s grisaille drawing portrays a sculpted personification of Wisdom, identified by the inscription “Sagesse” along her forehead. She is seated on a stone throne, decorated with two other female personifications on either side. Characterized as a righteous woman, Wisdom lifts her right arm in an authoritative gesture while clutching her traditional attribute, a crown of stars, in her other hand.
